data: Two non-joining fragments of a large marble plaque, perhaps c.80cm wide originally (so Manganaro). Both fragments are themselves broken in two and reconnected. Fragment (b) contains a single column of text, and is H 16 x W 10 x D 2 cm; Fragment (a) contains two columns of text, separated by a blank space, and measures H 23 x W 10 x D 2 cm. Manganaro notes the lettering to be similar and the dimensions compatible with belonging to a single large slab, perhaps from an honorific statue base.
Material from the excavation of the Villa Casale
L'année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l'antiquité romaine.

« L’année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l’antiquité romaine. », L’année épigraphique : revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l’antiquité romaine., 1888, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/630058599
Die Villa von Piazza Armerina, Residenz des kaiserlichen Prokurators, und ein mit ihr verbundenes Emporium von Henna

Giacomo Manganaro, ‘Die Villa von Piazza Armerina, Residenz des kaiserlichen Prokurators, und ein mit ihr verbundenes Emporium von Henna’, in Palast und Hütte : Beiträge zum Bauen und Wohnen im Altertum von Archäologen, Vor- und Frühgeschichtlern: Tagungsbeiträge eines Symposiums der Alexander von Humboldt-Stiftung, Bonn-Bad Godesberg, veranstaltet vom 25.-30. November 1979 in Berlin, ed. D. Papenfuss and V.M. Strocka (Mainz: Philipp von Zabern, 1982), 493–513
La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano
Giacomo Manganaro, «La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano», Aufstieg und Niedergang der romischen Welt 2.11.1 (1988): 3–89
Note storiche ed epigrafiche per la villa (praetorium) del Casale di Piazza Armerina
Giacomo Manganaro, «Note storiche ed epigrafiche per la villa (praetorium) del Casale di Piazza Armerina», Sicilia Antiqua 2 (2005): 173–91
Jonathan Prag checked encoding and added metadata

Italy Sicily Piazza Armerina Villa Romana del Casale Latin

Two non-joining fragments of a large marble plaque, perhaps c.80cm wide originally (so Manganaro). Both fragments are themselves broken in two and reconnected. Fragment (b) contains a single column of text, and is H 16 x W 10 x D 2 cm; Fragment (a) contains two columns of text, separated by a blank space, and measures H 23 x W 10 x D 2 cm. Manganaro notes the lettering to be similar and the dimensions compatible with belonging to a single large slab, perhaps from an honorific statue base.

cum Publium Cornelium omnis civis et decu rionum ordo patronum cooptaverit grati asque agere volens ei obtulerit hunc honorem itus templi et ma ceries per fundum suum debereetur sub no mine corona cum decurionum ordo Publium Cornelium auxilio municipio iudi casset curavit decretum in aes incidi et mitti tabula patrono bene merenti et ut omni bus notum fieret statuam Publi Corneli
deberetur et templi itus et maceries per fundum suum hoc nomine dicaverit eandem coronam us ex decurionum decreto pervenire possit Prisco · IIduum ·viro
Text of Magnanaro's 2005 reconstruction, making fragment (b) part of the left hand column, below fragment (a). The restorations are obviously highly speculative.
